The text here is written in French and English so to be accessible to international audiences
Note that the university is credited for creating the data visualization instead of just Du Bois.
"It's a really stark image because basically you have this huge block of black that says slaves and then free or libre is in green, and that's so small. The block of black is visually overpowering," says Rusert.
"It's really significant that we have this block of black that says slaves on it," says Rusert. "One of the broader rhetorics of the Paris exhibition and of all World's Fairs, period, was they were supposed to showcase the industrial progress and also civilizing powers of the European superpowers of the world as well as the United States. And one of the things that is so interesting throughout the images and this image in particular is that Du Bois and his students are continually questioning that narrative about civilization, and also about industrial progress."
This data visualization demonstrates how recent the institution of slavery was, says Rusert. "It really also challenges some of the [World Fair's] imperial narratives more broadly by insisting that slavery and slave labor and black labor more broadly is the base upon which American modernity stands," she says.
